CJ110.name: Introduction to Criminal Justice
CJ110.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ110.description: Description and analysis of agencies and processes involved in administration of justice in the United States.

CJ210.name: Introduction to Forensic Science
CJ210.description: Techniques of crime scene search. Collection and preservation of physical evidence. Class and individual scientific tests. Rules of evidence governing admissibility of physical evidence. Expert testimony.

CJ220.name: Criminology
CJ220.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ220.description: Introduction to the socio-legal foundation of crime. Crime typology and measurement procedures. Theory and public policy. Societal responses to crime and criminals.
CJ220.restrictions: Open to students in the Peace and Justice Studies Minor or in the Sociology Major or in the Youth and Society Minor or in the Criminal Justice Major or in the Law, Justice, and Public Policy Minor or in the Conservation and Environmental Law Enforcement Minor or approval of school.

CJ235.name: Investigation Procedures
CJ235.description: Laws of evidence controlling investigative procedures. Crime scene concerns. Multi-agency investigation.

CJ275.name: Criminal Procedure
CJ275.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ275.description: Administration of criminal law. Investigation, prosecution, adjudication, and sentencing. Constitutional safeguards and legal controls on official action.

CJ292.name: Methods of Criminal Justice Research
CJ292.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ292.description: Logic, design, analysis, and ethical principles in criminal justice research. Indicators of crime and its control.
CJ292.restrictions: Not open to freshmen and open to students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ294.name: Leadership and Professional Development in Criminal Justice
CJ294.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ294.description: Career planning and professional development. Leadership principles and theory, as related to the field of criminal justice.
CJ294.restrictions: Open to freshmen or sophomores in the School of Criminal Justice or approval of school.

CJ335.name: Policing
CJ335.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ335.description: Roles, responsibilities, issues, and trends pertinent to contemporary law enforcement organizations in contemporary society.
CJ335.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Criminal Justice Major or in the Conservation and Environmental Law Enforcement Minor.

CJ355.name: Juvenile Justice
CJ355.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ355.description: The juvenile justice system and law. Theories of juvenile delinquency and deviance. Sociological, psychological, and anthropological perspectives.
CJ355.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Peace and Justice Studies Minor or in the Criminal Justice Major.

CJ365.name: Corrections
CJ365.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ365.description: Historical and contemporary views of offender management and treatment. Corrections system operation. Effects of institutionalization. Alternatives to incarceration.
CJ365.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Criminal Justice Major.

CJ385.name: Private Security
CJ385.description: Relationships of private protective services with public law enforcement. Individuals, businesses, and governments providing prevention, protection, investigation, and disaster recovery services. Protection of persons, property, and information.
CJ385.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Criminal Justice Major or in the Security Management Minor.

CJ422.name: Comparative and Historical Criminal Justice
CJ422.description: Comparative study of criminal justice systems. Theories, types, and effects of intervention.
CJ422.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Criminal Justice Major.

CJ424.name: Crime, Mass Media, and Society (W)
CJ424.description: Representation of crime and criminal justice in the media. Relationship between media and criminal justice organizations. Images of crime, criminal justice, and trafficking. Media effects on criminal justice policy.
CJ424.restrictions: Open to seniors in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ425.name: Women and Criminal Justice
CJ425.description: Theories on women's victimization and criminality. Women's experiences as victims, offenders, and criminal justice employees. Laws and their effects on the rights of women in the criminal justice system.

CJ426.name: Violence Against Women (W)
CJ426.description: Intimate partner violence, rape and stalking. Theoretical causes of violence against women and factors commonly associated with it. Physical, mental and legal consequences, institutional responses and prevention efforts.
CJ426.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
CJ426.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Criminal Justice or approval of school.

CJ427.name: Criminology and Public Policy (W)
CJ427.description: Advanced study of criminological theory. Examination of policies implied by different theories of crime. Evaluation of crime control policies.
CJ427.prerequisite: (CJ 110 and CJ 220) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
CJ427.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Criminal Justice Major.

CJ429.name: Interdisciplinary Topics in CyberSecurity
CJ429.description: Technical, legal, criminal, medical business, and communication aspects of CyberSecurity.
CJ429.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CJ430.name: Advanced Seminar in Policing (W)
CJ430.description: Advanced issues in policing. Police strategies and evaluation. Behavioral determinants of policing. Socialization and culture of police. Police coercion. Police deviance.
CJ430.prerequisite: (CJ 110 and CJ 220 and CJ 335) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
CJ430.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Criminal Justice Major.

CJ432.name: Community Policing
CJ432.description: Community policing philosophy, applications, issues, and contemporary research. Community policing models.
CJ432.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Criminal Justice Major.

CJ433.name: Law Enforcement Intelligence Operations
CJ433.description: Law enforcement intelligence as an analytic tool for case development and resource allocation. Historical, ethical, legal, and operational issues affecting current practice.
CJ433.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Criminal Justice Major.

CJ434.name: Police Administration
CJ434.description: Organizational theory, leadership, communications, and labor relations in police administration. Historical and legal perspectives.
CJ434.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Criminal Justice Major.

CJ439.name: Homeland Security
CJ439.description: Definition of terrorism and terrorist groups. Fundamental principles of emergency management and homeland security. Historical perspectives and modern threats. Public health and environmental protection. Private sector role and impacts. Security vs. civil liberties. Science, technology, and research issues.
CJ439.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Defense Studies and Leadership Minor or in the Criminal Justice Major.

CJ445.name: Cyber-Crime and Cyber-Security (W)
CJ445.description: Internet crimes and problems and procedures for cybersecurity.
CJ445.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
CJ445.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Criminal Justice or approval of school.

CJ450.name: Introduction to Product Counterfeiting
CJ450.description: Introduction to the crime of product counterfeiting through an analysis of theory, empirical studies, and case histories. Understanding of product counterfeiting.

CJ465.name: Critical Issues in Corrections (W)
CJ465.description: Advanced topics in corrections. Probation and parole. Community corrections. Recidivism and reentry. Evolution of punishment. Comparative systems of confinement.
CJ465.prerequisite: (CJ 365) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
CJ465.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Criminal Justice major.

CJ466.name: Corrections Organizations and Systems
CJ466.description: Management of correctional organizations. Interactions between correctional organizations and their political and cultural environments.
CJ466.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Criminal Justice Major.

CJ471.name: Law of Corrections
CJ471.description: Constitutional limitations and the impact of law on correctional practice. Due process, prisoners' rights, and parole and probation.
CJ471.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Criminal Justice Major.

CJ473.name: Comparative Constitutional Law
CJ473.description: Comparative constitutional law. Courts with constitutional jurisdiction. Allocation of constitutional powers. Relationship among levels of government. Individual constitutional rights.

CJ474.name: Law and Criminal Justice Policy
CJ474.description: Impact of law on police practices, court processes, and corrections institutions and programs. Development, implementation, and evaluation of judicial policies.
CJ474.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Criminal Justice or in the Interdisciplinary Studies in Social Science major.

CJ485.name: Critical Issues in Private Security
CJ485.description: Advanced topics in private security. Planning and administering. Organizing and staffing. Human relations. Management styles. Media relations.
CJ485.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ490.name: Independent Study
CJ490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CJ490.description: Individual study in fields of criminal justice, under direct supervision of a faculty member.
CJ490.prerequisite: CJ 335 or CJ 355 or CJ 365 or CJ 385
CJ490.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Criminal Justice Major. Approval of school.

CJ491.name: Topics in Criminal Justice
CJ491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ491.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Criminal Justice major.

CJ494.name: Criminal Justice Practicum
CJ494.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CJ494.description: Observation, participation, and study in selected criminal justice agencies.
CJ494.prerequisite: CJ 335 or CJ 355 or CJ 365 or CJ 385
CJ494.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Criminal Justice. Approval of school.

CJ801.name: Crime Causation, Prevention, and Control
CJ801.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ801.description: Theories of crime causation. Translation of theory to policy.
CJ801.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice .

CJ802.name: Proseminar in Law Enforcement Intelligence Operations
CJ802.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CJ802.description: Law enforcement intelligence as an analytic tool for case development and resource allocation. Historical, ethical, legal, and operational issues affecting current practice.
CJ802.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Criminal Justice major or in the Law Enforcement Intelligence and Analysis major.

CJ803.name: Foundations in Homeland Security
CJ803.description: Homeland security's definition of terrorism and terrorist groups. Fundamental principles of emergency management and homeland security. Historical perspectives and modern threats. Public health and environmental protections. Private sector role and impacts. Security versus civil liberties. Science technology and research issues.
CJ803.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Criminal Justice major or in the Law Enforcement Intelligence and Analysis major.

CJ804.name: Crime Scene Investigation
CJ804.description: Introduction to crime scene investigation. Documentation, evidence collection, presumptive chemical and biological tests, and collection and preservation of impression evidence.
CJ804.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Forensic Science Major.

CJ805.name: Survey in Forensic Science
CJ805.description: Scientific analysis of physical evidence. Four major aspects of physical evidence using real criminal and civil cases
CJ805.restrictions: Open to students in the Forensic Science Major.

CJ809.name: Issues in Criminal Justice
CJ809.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CJ809.description: Special issues in criminal justice research and management.
CJ809.restrictions: Open only to master's students in the School of Criminal Justice or to doctoral students in the Social Science-Criminal Justice major.

CJ810.name: Proseminar in Criminal Justice
CJ810.description: Survey of classical and recent literature in criminal justice. Trends and issues that transcend the components of the criminal justice system.
CJ810.restrictions: Open only graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ811.name: Design and Analysis in Criminal Justice Research
CJ811.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ811.description: Scientific methods in criminal justice research. Design, data collection and analysis, interpretation of findings, and ethical concerns. Computer use in data analysis.
CJ811.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice .

CJ812.name: Criminal Justice Management Seminar
CJ812.description: Organization theory and behavior for the criminal justice agency. Organization and policy planning, budgeting, forecasting, human resource management, and project implementation.
CJ812.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice or approval of school.

CJ814.name: Seminar in Management Topics
CJ814.description: Critical application of selected analytical tools to managing justice agencies. Human and financial resources. Organizational design. Productivity measurement and enhancement. Resource acquisition and allocation.
CJ814.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ815.name: Proseminar in Criminal Investigation
CJ815.description: Research on the criminal justice process. Investigation and role of evidence in the administration of justice. Ethical issues.
CJ815.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ817.name: Law and Forensic Science
CJ817.description: Legal aspects of forensic science. Adjudicative process, admissibility of scientific evidence, laboratory reports, hearsay, relevant case materials, and expert testimony.
CJ817.restrictions: Open to students in the Forensic Science Major.

CJ819.name: Forensic Analysis of Drugs and Alcohol
CJ819.description: Techniques and processes in analysis of physical evidence including spectroscopy, chromatography, and microscopy. Emphasis on controlled substances.
CJ819.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Forensic Science Major.

CJ820.name: Forensic Chemistry and Microscopic Evidence
CJ820.description: Continuation of CJ 819. Analysis of trace evidence including hairs and fibers, paints and coatings, explosives and fire residues, glass and soil.
CJ820.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Forensic Science Major.

CJ821.name: Food Protection and Defense
CJ821.description: Food systems and criminal justice approaches to prepare for and solve issues relating to food safety and defense.
CJ821.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Veterinary Medicine or in the Food Safety major or in the Veterinary Medicine major or in the Criminal Justice major or approval of college.

CJ822.name: Comparative Criminal Justice
CJ822.description: Globalization, crime causation, measurement, and control in comparative and cross-national contexts. Nature of policing, courts, and corrections in select countries.
CJ822.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ823.name: Globalization of Crime
CJ823.description: International crimes and organized crime. Trafficking in women, children, and body parts. Related problems such as firearm violence, money laundering, and corruption that transcend national boundaries.
CJ823.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ829.name: National and Global Trends in Court Planning
CJ829.description: Emerging judicial trends. Stakeholder expectations. Impact on judicial branch planning. Regional, national, and global trends that frame strategic issues, planning, actions, and leadership.
CJ829.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice or approval of school.

CJ830.name: Foundations of Police Studies
CJ830.description: Police practice. The police role, socialization, discretion, strategies, deviance.
CJ830.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ836.name: Assessment of Police Policies and Operations
CJ836.description: Recent policy-related research and its application to the deployment of human resources.
CJ836.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ837.name: The Intelligence Process and Counterterrorism
CJ837.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ837.description: Law enforcement intelligence process for domestic and international terrorist threats. Current issues and trends in terrorism and counterterrorism, and the role of law enforcement intelligence.
CJ837.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ838.name: Issues in Terrorism
CJ838.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CJ838.description: Origins, history, and mutable definitions of terrorism. Ideologies, organizational features, ideologies, and state responses. Influential contemporary and historical terrorist movements. Force multipliers and media.
CJ838.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ839.name: Analytic Thinking and Intelligence
CJ839.description: Analytic processes, tools, applications, and contemporary issues as used in law enforcement intelligence processes.
CJ839.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice or approval of school.

CJ840.name: Anti-Counterfeit Strategy and Product Protection
CJ840.description: Theory and applied techniques for anti-counterfeit strategies and product protection for food and consumer products.
CJ840.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice or in the School of Packaging or in the Food Safety major or approval of department.

CJ845.name: Environmental Risk Perception and Decision-Making
CJ845.description: Theoretical underpinnings of individual decision-making and risk perception processes. Case studies of the interplay of risk perception and decision-making in an environmental and or criminological context.
CJ845.restrictions: Open to master's students or doctoral students in the School of Criminal Justice or in the Department of Fisheries and Wildlife or approval of school.

CJ846.name: Corporate Environmental Crime and Risk
CJ846.description: Theoretical accounts and multiple interventions relevant to corporate environmental crime and risk. Use of “Smart Regulation” principles to design interventions to match specific problems.
CJ846.restrictions: Open to master's students or doctoral students in the Department of Fisheries and Wildlife or in the School of Criminal Justice or approval of school.

CJ847.name: Global Risks, Conservation, and Criminology
CJ847.description: Theories, actors, characteristics and legal instruments associated with risk, conservation, and criminology related to globalization. Current case studies in criminological conservation.
CJ847.restrictions: Open to graduate students or approval of school.

CJ850.name: Product Counterfeiting
CJ850.description: Advanced theoretical and empirical perspectives from criminology, victimology, and organizational behavior to analyze the crime of product counterfeiting.

CJ856.name: Advanced Topics in Policing
CJ856.description: Special topics on policing such as crime analysis, problem solving, police recruitment, retention and development, police behavior and ethics.
CJ856.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice or approval of school.

CJ858.name: Gender, Justice and Environmental Change : Issues and Concepts
CJ858.description: Issues and concepts related to gender, ecology, and environmental studies. Key debates and theoretical approaches to addressing environmental issues from a gender and social justice perspective. Gender and environment issues and processes from a global perspective.

CJ860.name: Historical Foundations/Contemporary Frameworks of Judicial Administration
CJ860.description: Foundations in the legal and historical evolution of courts. Contemporary methods, practices, and theories of court administration, including purposes and responsibilities of courts, rule of law, caseflow management, and court governance and leadership models.
CJ860.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice or approval of department.

CJ861.name: Budget Planning and Resource Allocation for Court Performance
CJ861.description: Financial resources for courts and court systems. Resource acquisition and allocation strategies, output and outcome measurement for expenditure assessment, efficient and effective resource management, techniques for budget presentation in the public-sector context, alternative budget planning and justification formats, audit formats, revenue enhancement sources and strategies.
CJ861.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice or approval of department.

CJ862.name: Workforce Planning and Management in the Courts
CJ862.description: Workforce planning and management in the judicial branch. Selections and forms of employment, including elected and appointed judges and other judicial officers, at-will employees, civil servants, contractual labor and services. Succession planning, methods of employee development, coaching, mentoring, and continuing education.
CJ862.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice or approval of department.

CJ863.name: Courthouse Planning: Space, Technology, Security, and Disaster Recovery
CJ863.description: Planning for building or remodeling of courthouse and courtroom facilities. Requirements for federal and state courts. Safe public space, efficient workflow, technology infrastructure for electronic courts, security, and disaster planning and recovery.
CJ863.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice or approval of department.

CJ864.name: Elements of Essential Court Operations
CJ864.description: Court management infrastructure systems. Contemporary developments in problem-solving courts. Methods for measuring court inputs, outputs, and outcomes. Constitutional mandates, judicial branch independence and interdependence, transparency, and accountability.
CJ864.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice or approval of department.

CJ865.name: Adult Corrections
CJ865.description: Traditional and contemporary adult correctional practices. Social, political, economic, and organizational factors affecting correctional policies.
CJ865.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ870.name: Introduction to Crime Analysis
CJ870.description: Theoretical foundations of crime analysis. Techniques and processes used by law enforcement agencies to document and respond to patterns of crime.
CJ870.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Criminal Justice Major or in the Law Enforcement Intelligence and Analysis Major.

CJ871.name: Advanced Crime Analysis
CJ871.description: Advanced application of intelligence and crime analysis skills and techniques.

CJ872.name: Open Source Information Analysis
CJ872.description: Techniques for collection and intelligence analysis of open source information. Ethical issues for collection of publicly available information and validation of sources.

CJ885.name: Security Management
CJ885.description: Organization and management of security operations in business, industry, and government.
CJ885.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ886.name: Security Administration
CJ886.description: Administrative and quantitative techniques for security operations. Statistical analyses. Analysis of financial statements. Operations research and computer techniques.
CJ886.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ887.name: Quantitative Methods in Criminal Justice Research
CJ887.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ887.description: Descriptive and inferential statistics and computer use in criminal justice research.
CJ887.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Criminal Justice Major or in the Judicial Administration Major.

CJ890.name: Independent Study
CJ890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CJ890.description: Individual research and writing under faculty supervision.
CJ890.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice. Approval of school.

CJ894.name: Practicum
CJ894.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CJ894.description: Observation, study, and work in selected criminal justice agencies. Participation in domestic and foreign criminal justice systems.
CJ894.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice. Approval of school.

CJ895.name: Methods for Policy Development and Implementation
CJ895.description: Public policy process and organizational change with regard to crime and justice. Methods and techniques for diagnosing problems, designing policies, and implementing change in organizations and governmental jurisdictions.
CJ895.restrictions: Open to master's students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ896.name: Policy Analysis under Conditions of Change
CJ896.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CJ896.description: Methods of policy analysis in criminal justice settings. Policy analysis for the formulation, adoption, and implementation of changes.
CJ896.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice .

CJ897.name: Comprehensive Threat Assessment
CJ897.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CJ897.description: Methods of conducting a comprehensive threat assessment in criminal justice settings. Comprehensive threat assessment for the formulation, adoption, and implementation of prevention and intervention practices.
CJ897.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Law Enforcement Intelligence and Analysis Major.

CJ899.name: Master's Thesis Research
CJ899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CJ899.description: Planned research and writing directed by student's thesis committee.
CJ899.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ901.name: Seminar in Contemporary Criminal Justice Theory
CJ901.description: Theoretical perspectives and issues in criminal justice and criminology
CJ901.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Criminal Justice Major.

CJ904.name: Criminal Justice Organizations and Processes
CJ904.description: Theoretical perspectives on organizations and processes in criminal justice. Evaluation of organizational performance in justice agencies.
CJ904.restrictions: Open only to doctoral students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ905.name: Law and Society
CJ905.description: Theoretical perspectives on law. Impact of law on society and the criminal justice system.
CJ905.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Criminal Justice Major.

CJ906.name: Advanced Quantitative Methods in Criminal Justice Research
CJ906.description: Applications of quantitative techniques to criminal justice data. Use of multiple regression and SPSS.
CJ906.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Criminal Justice major.

CJ907.name: Advanced Topics in Criminal Justice Data Analysis
CJ907.description: Advanced quantitative analysis techniques for criminal justice data.
CJ907.restrictions: Open only to doctoral students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ908.name: Advanced Topics in Criminal Justice
CJ908.description: Intensive study of one subfield of criminal justice. Critical evaluation of the literature.
CJ908.restrictions: Open only to doctoral students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ909.name: Advanced Research Methods
CJ909.description: Methodological approaches to conducting sound, ethical criminal justice and criminological research. Research ethics, study design, and data collection methods.
CJ909.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the School of Criminal Justice.

CJ999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
CJ999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CJ999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Criminal Justice major.
